subSection.paragraph: ARTICLE INFO
Frankincense
Cembranoids
Chemistry
Biogenesis
Bioactivity
ABSTRACT

Frankincense of
Boswellia species
has long been used in traditional medicines, mainly for its interesting anti-inflammatory and anti-depressant properties of its di- and triterpenes. Boswellic acids (triterpenes) and cembranoids (diterpenes) are the major constituents of frankincense from all reported species which are responsible for the overall biological activity of frankincense. Boswellic acids have been thoroughly investigated for decades but cembranoids have attracted considerable attention only recently, and a good number of publications have highlighted the important role of these 14-membered rings in contributing to the superior anti-inflammatory activity of the sacred resin. Partial and total syntheses of some cembranoids from frankincense have been reported. Their therapeutic potential is not limited to the well proven anti-inflammatory activity but also to their recently reported anti-depressant properties.

There is a considerable number of publications in the field of cembranoids of
Boswellia species
where we feel a review in this topic will be of interest to the readership of Phytochemistry . In this article we have discussed the chemistry (isolation and chemical structures as well as synthetic studies), biogenesis and bioactivity of the reported cembranoids of
Boswellia species.
The structural discrepancies due to wrongly assigned structures of some cembranoids have been highlighted and corrected. We have covered the related literature up to the end of 2020.

Frankincense - a resin of
Boswellia
trees is the most precious resin religiously, socially, economically and medicinally. In an attempt to reviving its historical role in treating various chronic diseases, our group has been intensively involved in unravelling the secrets of this ancient resin. Boswellic acids and cembranoids are the major chemical constituents of frankincense with well documented medicinal properties. However, compared to boswellic acids which have been thoroughly reviewed, cembranoids have received less attention (Ahmed Al-Harrasi, Hidayat Hussain, Rene Csuk , 2018; Shah et al., 2009 ).
Kobayashi and Akiyoshi, 1962 ).

A large number of cembranoids have been reported from the various
Boswellia species.
Their structural complexities and important medicinal properties have attracted the attention of both chemists and biologists. They are now actively engaged in isolation, synthesis and exploration of new pharmacological activities of this group of compounds (Ahmed Al-Harrasi, Hidayat Hussain, Rene Csuk, 2018).

There is no comprehensive review on the cembranoids of
Boswellia species.
In this regard, with our research in the field, we would like to review the subject in detail. In this review we will discuss the chemistry, biogenesis and bioactivity of the reported cembranoids of
Boswellia species.
Furthermore, we will discuss the structural discrepancies of various cembranoids reported in literature. In our discussion we will cover the literature up to the end of 2020.

The chemistry of cembranoids of
Boswellia species
has been an important topic of investigation in recent years. The isolation and identification of a good number of cembranoids from
Boswellia

subSection.paragraph: prompted synthetic modifications of these interesting compounds. Partial and total syntheses of some of the isolates have also been performed.

There are 24 described species in the genus
Boswellia
distributed between South Arabia , Africa and India . The following table ( Table 1 ) summarizes all species with their synonyms and geographical locations.

The controversy in
Boswellia
taxonomy is huge despite the fact that only 24 species exist in this genus. This is partly due to the large chemical analyses that were based on commercial samples that lack information about the taxonomic origin (Ahmed Al-Harrasi, Hidayat Hussain, Rene Csuk, Husain Yar Khan, 2018 ; Al-Harrasi et al., 2019a ) but also due to the huge overlap of chemical constituents in the studied species.

The synonymy of
Boswellia sacra
growing in South Arabia ( Oman and Yamen) and
Boswellia carterii
growing in Africa was misleading. Some literature reports considered the two species to be the same, while others regarded them as different. This is still confusing and unless genomic studies supported by chemical analysis of the oil and resins are done, it will be difficult to prove or disprove their synonymy. Another controversy comes from the confusion between
Boswellia papyrifera
and
Boswellia carterii
but this was corrected in all publications after 2012.

Boswellia
is a natural factory of cembranoids. A large number of
Boswellia species
( Table 2 ) have been investigated for isolation of these compounds ( Table 2 , Fig. 2 ). Some of the compounds, such as incensole ( 6 ) and incensole acetate ( 7 ) have been reported from various
Boswellia species
( Al-Harrasi et al., 2019a ).

The cembranoids of the gum resin of
Boswellia species
were isolated by extraction of the material using different solvents such as n -hexane,

subSection.paragraph: MeOH, EtOH, etc. These extracts generally consisted of complex mixture of several chemical constituents. They were purified using various advanced chromatographic techniques including improved HPLC methods.

In general, Cembranoids are macrocyclic diterpenes comprising four isoprene units bonded head-to-tail, possessing 14-membered ring with three symmetrically distributed methyl groups and one isopropyl group. The cembrane nucleus has a symmetry plane with an axis passing through C-1 and C-8 (Weinheimer, C. W. J. ChangI. FlamentJ. A. MatsonT. NishidaG. OhloffF. W. WehrliA. J, 1979).

Some of the reported cembranes are detected by GCMS and therefore no structural elucidation is possible and hence no conformational studies exist. The stereochemistry of the chiral centers of compounds 6–9 was established based on NOE ( Li et al., 2010 ). The structure of rel (1 S , 3 R , 7 E , 11 S , 12 R )-1,12-epoxy-4-methylcembr-7-ene-3,11-diol ( 23 ) was confirmed by the HSQC and HMBC spectra. The relative stereochemistry was found to be in full agreement with that of incensole oxide ( 8 ) by the observed NOEs in a 2D NOESY spectrum (H2a + b/H18a, H-5a/H-18 b, H-6a/Me-19, H-7/H-9a, H-7/H-10a, H-10 b/Me-20, H-11/H-14a, H-11/Me-19). The absolute configuration of compound 8 is assumed as depicted in its structure because of the direct comparison with incensole oxide ( 8 ) that is evidenced by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis (Ren et al., 2015).

subSection.paragraph: Due to the fact that the absolute stereochemistry of C–1S has been unambiguously confirmed by X-ray analysis for the similar compound incensole oxide ( 8 ) ( Boscarelli et al., 1981 ) as well as by CD spectroscopy of Serratol ( 14 ) ( Schmidt et al., 2011 ), the enantiomeric assignment for isoincensole oxide ( 12) ( Fig. 3 ) as rel (1 S , 7 R , 8 S , 11 S , 12 R ) should be preferred ( Greve et al., 2017 ). This fact is supported by NOESY spectra that revealed cis arrangement of the isopropyl group with Me-20. This is, however, in contrast with Kato’ s proposal ( Kato et al., 1977 ) who suggested the E configuration. The NOE between H-15 and Me-20 confirms the cis arrangement of the isopropyl group and Me-20 (1S, 12R). Kato et al. proposed the configuration of C-11 as S due to the lack of NOE interactions between H-11 and Me-20. However, based on the molecular models proposed by Greve el al. ( Greve et al., 2017 ), this NOE should theoretically exist and it was interestingly seen in the NOESY experiment. It is therefore concluded that the stereochemistry at C-11 is confirmed as S . The lack of NOE interactions between H-7 and Me-19 indicates that these two groups are in trans position to each other. Furthermore, Kato et al. (1977) concluded that the stereochemistry of 7 R , 8 S attributed to a downfield shift of the olefinic proton when compared with the 7 S , 8 S epimer but they haven’ t compared it with the other diastereomer 7 S , 8 R . Greve et al. detected clear NOEs between H-3 and H-6a as well as between H-7 and H-13a in their NOESY experiment which further support the rel (1S,7S,8R,11S, 12R) configuration. Therefore, the stereochemistry of isoincensole oxide ( 12) is as proposed by Greve et al. (2017) , and adopted here.

subSection.paragraph: Schmidt et al. (2011) reported the complete structural assignment of serratol ( 14) where all proton and carbon resonances of serratol were resolved and unambiguously assigned for the first time based on HSQC and HMBC spectra.

We have reported ( Rehman et al., 2017 ) the full structural assignment and absolute configuration of incensfuran ( 21) by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis and electronic and vibrational circular dichroism spectroscopy (ECD, VCD). The relative stereochemistry at C-1, C-12, C-11, and C-8 was confirmed by the NOESY correlations of H-5 with Me-19 and Me-20, and of Me-17/16 with Me-20.

The stereochemistry of Boscartins A-H ( 30–37 ) was confirmed by NOESY experiments (Ren et al., 2015). The NOE correlations of compound 30 ( Fig. 4 ) has confirmed its relative configuration. The existence of NOE correlations of H-3/H-10a, H-11/H-10a, and H-10 b/Me-20 and the absence of NOE correlations of H-11/H-10 b and H-11/Me-20, suggested that OH-3 was in an α- position, OH-11 was in an exo and α- position, and Me-20 was in a β- position.

The NOE correlations of H-3/H-6b, H-7/H-6a, and H-7/Me-18 proved that both Me-18 and H-7 were in α- orientations. The NOE correlation of H-9 with Me-19 suggested that the olefinic geometry is 8 Z . Furthermore, the NOE correlation of H-3 with H-15 proved the β- orientation of the isopropyl group. Finally, the absolute configuration (1 S , 3 R , 4 S, 7 R , 8 Z , 11 S ,12 R ) was revealed by X-ray crystal structure. Details of NOESY experiments of the other Boscartins can be found in the original reference (Ren et al., 2015).

The configurations and structure of another group of Cembrane-type diterpenoids (Boscartins AH-AK 63–66 ) were established by analysis of NOESY experiments ( Sun et al., 2019 ). The NOE correlations of H-3/H-5b, H-7; H-6/H-7, Me-18, Me-19; H-7/H-3, H-5b; H-10a/Me-20, H-3, H-7, H-11; H-10 b/H-9; and H-11/H-3, H-10a, Me- 20 in cembrane 63 showed that H-3, H-6, H-7, H-10a, H-11, Me-18 and Me-20 were all in beta orientation, thus, the 3,4-oxirane, 6,7-oxirane and the acetyl group at C-11 are in alpha orientations. This confirmed the structure of this compound to be (1 S , 3 R , 4 S , 6 R , 7 R , 11 R , 12 R , 8 Z )-1:12,3:4, 6:7-triepoxy-11-acetoxy-8-cembrene.

subSection.paragraph:
Finally, Wang et al. (2020) ( Wang et al., 2020 ) described ten cembrane-type diterpenoids from the gum resin of
Boswellia sacra
. The relative configuration of compound 67A was established by means of the ROESY experiment which revealed a different relative configuration when compared with incensole oxide ( 8 ). The major key correlations from H-7 to H-5a, H-9a and Me-19 to H-6a, and H-9b; from H-15 to Me-16, Me-17, and Me-20; from Me 18 to Me-17, H-5b, and H-6a; from H-11 to H-13a, H-14a, H-3, and H-10; and the absence of correlations from H-11 to Me- 20 in the ROESY spectrum confirmed that the double bond was trans . Furthermore, the isopropyl groups, Me-18 and Me-20, were found to be in β- orientations while H-3 and H-11 were in α- orientations. These important correlations suggested opposite configurations of H-3 and Me-18 between 67 and incensole oxide ( 8 ) where H-3 was β- oriented and Me-18 was α- oriented. The absolute configuration of 67 was unequivocally confirmed by X-ray crystallographic analysis to be 1 S , 3 S , 4 S , 7 E , 11 S , 12 R .

The cembranoids of
Boswellia species
were found to possess fascinating structural patterns ( Fig. 1 ). Generally, they contain nuclear unsaturation with double bonds ( E or Z ) inside the 14-membered core along with various functional groups including hydroxyl, ether, ester and epoxide.

Frankincense (olibanum) is one of the oldest aromatic materials used by humans, and the key molecular constituents contributing to its characteristic odor are known now. The characteristic odor of frankincense is due to the presence of (1 S , 2 S )- (+)- trans - and (1 S , 2 R )- (+)- cis - 2-octylcyclopropyl-1-carboxylic acids which are highly potent and substantive odorants occurring a very small amounts (ppm) in all of the frankincense samples analyzed, even those showing radically different volatile compositions. These cyclopropyl-derived acids provide the very characteristic old churchlike endnote of the frankincense odor ( Cerutti-Delasalle et al., 2016 ).

The structures of the cembranoids were settled by a detailed investigation of their spectral properties, mainly their 1 H NMR, 13 C NMR and 2D data. Here, we provided spectral data of some representative cembranoids of compounds
30–33 in
Table 4 ( 1 H NMR) & Table 5 ( 13 C NMR).

Various chemical modifications and syntheses of cembranoids of
Boswellia species
have been carried out. These synthetic studies were accomplished mainly involving incensole and incensole acetate along with some other cembranoids. The results have been discussed in some earlier reports (Ahmed Al-Harrasi, Hidayat Hussain, Rene Csuk, Husain Yar Khan, 2018 ; Al-Harrasi et al., 2019a ).

Recently 5- epi -incensole ( 77 ) has been prepared from incensole acetate ( 7 ) (Avula et al., 2016). The latter was deacetylated to incensole ( 6 ) which subsequently underwent Jones oxidation followed by a reduction with NaBH 4 (Scheme 1).

An interesting protecting-group free enantioselective total synthesis of boscartin F ( 35 ) has recently been reported ( Matsuzawa et al., 2018 ). The compound exhibits X-box bonding protein transcriptional activity. The synthesis was initiated (Scheme 2) from known allyl alcohol ( 78 ) which - upon Sharpless epoxidation using L-DET and subsequent treatment with vinyl-Grignard reagent-afforded diol 79 . The mesylation/cyclization of 79 yielded an epoxide which was opened with a Grignard reagent, methallyl magnesium bromide, to furnish a tertiary alcohol 80 . The iodoetherification of alcohol 80 afforded the tetrahydrofuran 81 . The latter - when treated with KO 2 /18-crown-6 followed by a subsequent oxidation with IBX - generated aldehyde 82 . The other olefinic part 84 was prepared from the ester 83 by DIBAL-H reduction and HWE-olefination. The aldol reaction of 84 with 82 produced the adduct 85 . The structure and absolute configuration of 85 was confirmed by X-ray crystallographic analysis of its semicarbazone. Finally, a ring-closing metathesis (RCM) of 85 using Stewart-Grubb catalyst followed by epoxidation with m -CPBA provided natural boscartin F. The synthesis was completed in 10 steps with 3 % overall yield.

caption.paragraph: 1 H NMR (600 MHz) spectroscopic data of compounds 30–33 .

subSection.paragraph: Biosynthesis of cembranoids has been discussed by various researchers (Ahmed Al-Harrasi, Hidayat Hussain, Rene Csuk, Husain Yar Khan, 2018 ; Al-Harrasi et al., 2019a ; McMillan. J, 1999). Four steps are involved in the biogenesis of cembranoids. The first step is the formation of the isoprene unit through two different pathways, starting from 1-deoxyxylulose or mevalonic acid. The combination of the isoprene units results in the generation of geranylgeranyl pyrophosphate (GGPP) (isoprenoid) in the second step. Later, in the third step, cyclization of GGPP occurs via a carbenium ion to form the cembranoid core structure. Finally, in the fourth step functionalization (e.g. oxidation; hydroxylation etc.) of the skeleton of cembranoids takes place to form the various naturally occurring cembranoids (Scheme 3).

caption.paragraph: 13 C NMR spectroscopic data of compounds 30-33.

subSection.paragraph:
There are several biological activities associated with cembranoids of
Boswellia species.
The most important activities are the anti-inflammatory and anti-depression activities. Cembranoids in the genus
Boswellia
contribute to the overall activity of the frankincense.

The gum resin of
Boswellia species
has shown promising anti-inflammatory activity supported by clinical trials to treat rheumatoid
Scheme 1. Synthesis of 5- epi -incensole.

Incensole ( 6 ) and incensole acetate ( 7 ) ( Fig. 7 ) were evaluated as novel potential NF-κB inhibitors. Incensole acetate did not interfere with NNF-α induced activation of c-Jun-N-terminal kinase (JNK) and P38 nitrogen-activated protein kinase. The compound was found to inhibit the cytokine and bipopolysaccharide-mediated NF-KB activation. It inhibited the activation of loop phosphorylation of TAK-TAB mediated IKB kinase (IKK) but showed no effect on IKK activity in vitro and no suppression of IKB phosphorylation in co-stimulated T-cells ( Moussaieff et al, 2007 ,
2008 a
, 2008b). An in silico approach suggested that incensole ( 6 ) and incensole acetate ( 7 ) are excellent anti-psoriatic agents ( Halim et al., 2020 ).

Scheme 2. Total synthesis of boscartin F. Scheme 3. Biogenesis pathways of Cembranoids of
Boswellia species.
Scheme 4. Biogenetic pathway showing the formation of boscartin M (42). Scheme 5. Proposed biosynthetic pathways of the formation of boscartin-type cembranoids.

The cembranoid, (rel)-(1 S ,5 R ,7 E ,11 E )-1-isopropyl-8,12-dimethyl-4- methylenecyclotetradeca-7,11-diene-1,5-diol ( 24 ) was examined for its inhibitory effect on NO production in an in vitro inflammatory model of peritoneal macrophages of RAW Z647 molasse. The compound showed significant anti-inflammatory activity (IC 50 1.32 μM) when compared with the positive control, dexamethasone (IC 50 2.0 μM) (J.-Q. Yu et al., 2018).

The anti-protozoal activity of the cembranoid diterpenoids of
Boswellia species
was studied with serratol ( 14 ). The compound was found to be moderately active against the organisms,
Plasmodium falciparam
and
Trypanosoma brucei ( Schmidt et al., 2011 )
.

The crude extract of the oleogum resin of
Boswellia serrata
showed anti-plasmodial effect in vitro -it was active against
P. falciparam .
The cembranoids (including cembrene A ( 2 ), serratol ( 14 ) and incensole acetate ( 7 )) isolated from the extract were less active than the crude material ( Greve et al., 2017 ).

The volatile oil of Frankincense of
Boswellia carterii
was subjected to a lymphocyte proliferation assay and was found to exhibit a strong immunostimulant activity (90 % lymphocyte transformation). Various cembranoids including cembrane and isocembrene were detected in this oil ( Mikhaeil et al., 2003 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 7. Structures of incensole (6) and incensole acetate (7).

subSection.paragraph:
Several cembranoids of the gum resin of
Boswellia carterii
were examined for their anti-ulcerative colitis activity (Ren et al., 2015). An in vitro X-box-binding protein 1 (XBP1) transcriptional activity assay was selected, and the duel luciferase reported detection method was applied. 9-Oxodihydrocoptisin was used as the positive control. At 10 μM concentration, boscartins A ( 30 ), F ( 35 ), G ( 36 ), H ( 37 ) significantly activated XBP1 transcription. This study indicated that the gum resin of
Boswellia carterii
can be utilized to treat ulcers.

In the present article we have reviewed the reported chemistry, biogenesis and bioactivity of cembranoids
Boswellia species.
The structural discrepancies of some of the compounds have been discussed. The biogenesis of different cembranoids has been illustrated. The isolated cembranoids of
Boswellia species
are associated with various bioactivities.

document.paragraph: Ahmed Al-Harrasi received his BSc in Chemistry from Sultan
University of Berlin from which he obtained his MSc in
Chemistry in 2002 and then his PhD in Organic Chemistry in
2005 as a DAAD-fellow under the supervision of Prof. Hans-
Ulrich Reissig. His PhD work was on New Transformations of
Enantiopure 1,2-oxazines. Then he received the Fulbright
award in 2008 for postdoctoral research in chemistry for which
he joined Prof.Tadhg Begely group at Cornell University where
he worked on Synthesis of isotopically-labeled thiamin pyro-
phosphate. After a postdoctoral research stay at Cornell Uni-
versity in 2009, he started his independent research at the
University of Nizwa, Oman where he founded the chair of
Oman’ s Medicinal Plants and Marine Natural Products merging chemistry and biology research that became a center of excellent in natural and medical sciences. He is currently

a professor of organic chemistry and the vice chancellor for graduate studies, research and external relations at the University of Nizwa. The budget of his interdisciplinary-funded projects exceeds 10 million USD. He was a chair and invited speaker in many international conferences. He is a referee for more than 15 international chemistry and biotechnology Journals. He has authored and co-authored over 400 scientific papers, three books and 10 book chapters. He taught chemistry courses both at undergraduate and postgraduate levels. He is named in Stanford University’ s global list of top 2 % Scientists in year 2019–2020.
Satya Kumar Avula, a Research Assistant Professor in organic
chemistry, Natural & Medical Sciences Research Center
work (Supervisor: Dr. Biswanath Das) in Indian Institute of
Chemical Technology (IICT, CSIR Lab), Hyderabad, India and
received his Ph.D. degree in Organic Chemistry from Jawa-
harlal Nehru Technological University Hyderabad (JNTUH-
IICT), India in 2012. He then moved to the University of Kwa-
Zulu Natal (UKZN), Durban, South Africa collaborated with
Uppsala University, Sweden as a Postdoctoral Researcher
(2012–2013) in the group of Prof. Anderson. He has been
involved in chemical transformations and total stereoselective
synthesis of natural products, Dr. Kumar has published 35 ar-
ticles in a peer reviewed international journals. He has presented his research work at various national and international conferences.
Rene´Csuk, was born in Zurich / Switzerland and is Austrian
citizen. He got his academic education at the University of
Technology in Graz/ Austria , and received both his diploma
(1981) and his PhD thesis (1984) under the supervision of Prof.
Hans Weidmann “with distinction”. After having been
appointed to a University Lecturer in 1984 for advanced NMR
spectroscopic methods, he moved 1986 for a postgraduate

paragraph.materialsCitation: study to Zurich ( Prof. Andrea T. Vasella ) working in the field of

document.paragraph: the total synthesis of natural products. He joined 1989 the
group of Prof. Richard Neidlein at the Ruprecht-Karls Univer-
sity Heidelberg, and finished his “Habilitation” in 1992
(“Pharmaceutical Chemistry”) and was appointed Associate
Professor(C3) in the same year (“Pharmaceutical Chemistry
and Pharmaceutical Biochemistry”). He is since 1995 full professor of Organic Chemistry (C4) at the Martin- Luther-University Halle-Wittenberg. During 1996 until 2003 he served
as a dean to his faculty, was appointed in 2001 as a director of the “Biocenter Halle”, 2015

as fellow of the Royal Chemical Society and in the same year as an editor of the “Europ. J. Med. Chem.” Prof. Csuk has authored more than 250 scientific papers, 12 books or book chapters and several patents. His main interests are natural products, stereoselective synthesis, chemoenzymatics and the synthesis of anti-tumor, anti-viral and anti-dementia active compounds, but he is also interested in historic and ancient dyes and colorants.

Biswanath Das, M.Sc. (1st Class, 1st Rank) received Ph.D. from Calcutta University (Supervisor: Professor Asima Chatterjee) and continued his Post-Doc work in US Supervisor: Professor D. G. I. Kingston). He has been associated with various famous academic Institutes (IICT, India ; CYUT, Taiwan ; Nizwa University, Oman ) and Industrial organizations (in Hyderabad, Bengaluru, India ). His field of research is Chemistry of Bioactive Organic Compounds (natural products and synthetic compounds). Dr. Das has several research publications (in SI Journals), book articles and patents to his credit. He has delivered lectures in various national and international seminars and symposia. He is honored with different prestigious awards. Recently he has been recognized (Stanford University)
as “One of the World Top Scientists” from India .
